maml:description.maml:para: Adds a static mapping to a NAT instance.

The Add-NetNatStaticMapping cmdlet adds a static mapping to a network address translation (NAT) instance. A static mapping enables an incoming connection from an external network to access a host on an internal network through the NAT.

You can use NAT to share a connection to the public Internet through a single interface with a single public IP address. The computers on the private network use private, non-routable addresses. NAT maps the private addresses to the public address.
Specifies the name of the NAT instance.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the internal port to which the packets from a remote machine in the external network are sent. If you do not specify this parameter, NAT uses the port that you specify for the ExternalPort parameter for the internal port.
Specifies the GUID of the routing domain of the internal interface.
Specifies the IP address prefix of the remote computer on the external network.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies the external IP address to which an incoming connection is addressed. This parameter specifies the destination IP address in the incoming packet
Specifies the external port to which an incoming connection is sent. This parameter specifies the destination port in the incoming TCP or UDP packets.
Specifies the IP address to which the packets from a remote machine in the external network are addressed.

Specifies the network protocol of the client computer in the internal network. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- TCP -- UDP
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies the external IP address to which an incoming connection is addressed. This parameter specifies the destination IP address in the incoming packet
Specifies the external port to which an incoming connection is sent. This parameter specifies the destination port in the incoming TCP or UDP packets.
Specifies the IP address to which the packets from a remote machine in the external network are addressed.

Specifies the internal port to which the packets from a remote machine in the external network are sent. If you do not specify this parameter, NAT uses the port that you specify for the ExternalPort parameter for the internal port.
Specifies the GUID of the routing domain of the internal interface.
Specifies the name of the NAT instance.

Specifies the network protocol of the client computer in the internal network. The acceptable values for this parameter are:
-- TCP -- UDP
Specifies the IP address prefix of the remote computer on the external network.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Add a static mapping to a NAT instance

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command adds a static mapping to a NAT instance. The command specifies that NAT maps the external IP address to the internal IP address 192.0.02.179. The command specifies that the NAT maps the destination port 80 of the Internet resource to the source application port 8080. The command specifies that the tenant compartment that has the ID TSQATenant contains the internal address and internal port. This example uses the placeholder a.b.c.0/24 to represent a public Internet address prefix.

maml:description.maml:para: Gets static mappings configured on NAT instances.

The Get-NetNatMapping cmdlet gets static mappings configured on network address translation (NAT) instances. A static mapping enables an incoming connection from an external network to an internal network through the NAT.
Specifies an array of names of NAT instances.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies an array of names of NAT instances.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Get static mappings of NAT instances

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command gets all static mappings of NAT instances configured on the local computer.

maml:description.maml:para: Removes static mappings from a NAT instance.

The Remove-NetNatStaticMapping cmdlet removes one or more static mappings configured on network address translation (NAT) instances. A static mapping enables an incoming connection from an external network to an internal network through the NAT.
Specifies an array of names of NAT instances.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies an array of static mapping IDs.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Specifies an array of NAT static mapping objects. To obtain a NAT static mapping object, use the Get-NetNatStaticMapping cmdlet.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.
Shows what would happen if the cmdlet runs. The cmdlet is not run.

Runs the cmdlet as a background job. Use this parameter to run commands that take a long time to complete. The cmdlet immediately returns an object that represents the job and then displays the command prompt. You can continue to work in the session while the job completes. To manage the job, use the *-Job cmdlets. To get the job results, use the Receive-Job cmdlet. For more information about Windows PowerShell® background jobs, see about_Jobs.

Runs the cmdlet in a remote session or on a remote computer. Enter a computer name or a session object, such as the output of a New-CimSession or Get-CimSession cmdlet. The default is the current session on the local computer.
Specifies an array of NAT static mapping objects. To obtain a NAT static mapping object, use the Get-NetNatStaticMapping cmdlet.
Specifies an array of names of NAT instances.
Returns an object representing the item with which you are working. By default, this cmdlet does not generate any output.
Specifies an array of static mapping IDs.

Specifies the maximum number of concurrent operations that can be established to run the cmdlet. If this parameter is omitted or a value of 0 is entered, then Windows PowerShell® calculates an optimum throttle limit for the cmdlet based on the number of CIM cmdlets that are running on the computer. The throttle limit applies only to the current cmdlet, not to the session or to the computer.
Prompts you for confirmation before running the cmdlet.

command:example.maml:title: Example 1: Remove all static mappings from a NAT instance

dev:remarks.maml:para: This command removes all static mapping of NAT instances configured on the local computer.
